EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

This Risk Management Plan (RMP) is prepared for Barber¿s BEI Hawaii - Point facility, formerly know as Brewer Environmental Industries, LLC.  BEI Hawaii developed this site specific Risk Management Plans for BEI Hawaii¿s facility that are regulated under risk management program to comply with Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Accidental Release Prevention requirements: Risk Management Programs under Clean Air Act Section 112(r) and to protect public safety and environment.  The goal of our risk management program is to prevent serious chemical accidents that could cause harm to our employees, the general publics, and the environment and to reduce the potential impact of the accidental release.  

This RMP consists of four chapters.  Chapter 1, Introduction and Management System, introduces the plans and describes the facility operations, management and responsibilities.  Chapter 2, Hazardous Assessment, provides an overview of the chemicals stored in our Barbers Point facility, their hazard release consequences and impact in worst case and alternative scenario.  Chapter 3, five-year accident History.  Chapter 4, Prevention Program, provides some safety information, hazard analysis, operation procedures, and prevention procedures.  Chapter 5, Summary of Emergency Response program.

1.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

BEI Hawaii believes in a clean and safe environment and is dedicated to meeting all applicable environmental standards in the operation of its businesses and services.  BEI Hawaii has established comprehensive policies and procedures for the operations of its facilities.  The policy is a commitment to environmental compliance that assigns the responsibility of implementing the policy to Chief Executive Officer of the company, or designated individual or individuals to ensure compliance.   The purpose of the policy is to provide employees with a safe and healthy working environment, and to protect the

environmental from pollutions.

Preservation of the environment is a commitment that must be shared by all employees.  Employees shall promptly report suspected violations of environmental laws, regulations or permits to their supervisor who shall take immediate action to verify the report and, if confirmed, stop the violation and take remedial or other appropriate action.   The incident shall be promptly reported to BEI Hawaii¿s Regulatory Compliance manager, who will assist in making any necessary reports to regulatory agencies.

Overall approach to chemical safety begins with the premise that safety is everyone¿s responsibility and working safely is a condition of employment. Workplace hazards are minimized through preventive measures such as facility and equipment design, purchase of less hazardous products and development of standard operating procedures. Control measures include facility inspections to discover potential problems, employee reports of hazardous conditions, training and a safety award program.   

2.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substance 

Our BEI Hawaii - Barber¿s Point facility is located at 91-150 Kaomi Loop, Kapolei, on the island of Oahu.  The site is leasehold with Campbell Estates being the leaseholder and consists of approximately 6.2 acres.   The site is bounded on the north by Chevron Hawaii Refinery, south and east by undeveloped parcels, and the Pacific Ocean and shoreline to the west.  The facility stores bulk and bagged industrial chemicals.  The products are mainly warehoused at the facility and distributed to various locations throughout Oahu customers as well as throughout the State of Hawaii.  The regulated substances handled at this storage/distribution facility are chlorine, sulfur dioxide (anhydrous) and anhydrous ammonia.  All the materials are prepackaged by manufacture in Department of Transportation (DOT) approved cylinders or tankers.  BEI Hawaii receives them from the chemical suppliers and distributors located on

the west coast.  The suppliers are responsible for container inspection and maintenance.  Because bulk sales are made directly to customers, access to the facility is not restricted.

3.  Release Scenarios

Two release scenarios (worst case scenario and alternative scenario) have been assessed for chlorine, anhydrous Sulfur Dioxide and Anhydrous ammonia.

Chlorine:
Worst-case release scenario ¿ failure of a 1-ton chlorine cylinder releases 2,000 pounds of chlorine within a 10-minute time frame.  It is assumed that the entire contents of the cylinder are released as a dense vapor cloud.  The ERPG-2 toxic endpoint (for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L [~3 ppm]) was predicted to be 1.3 miles downwind of the facility.  The EPA model RMP*Comp (version 1.07) was used to estimate the toxic endpoint distance assuming worst-case meteorology of 1.5 m/s stability class F, no mitigation measures, and that the material is stored as liquid under pressure.

Alternative-case release scenario ¿ 2000 - pound chlorine cylinder falls over and shears off the valve, leaves a 1¿ circular hole on the cylinder releasing 150 lbs per minutes of chlorine in a 14-minute time frame.  It is assumed that the entire contents of the cylinder are released as a dense vapor cloud.  The ERPG-2 toxic endpoint (for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L [~3 ppm]) was predicted to be 0.2 miles downwind of the facility.  The EPA model RMP*Comp was used to estimate the toxic endpoint distance assuming average meteorology of 3.0 m/s stability class D, no mitigation measures, and that the material is stored as liquid under pressure.

The BEI HAWAII facility maintains two chlorine container emergency kits (one ¿A¿ kit for 150 lb cylinders and one ¿B¿ kit for 2,000 lb cylinders), and has a chlorine recovery vessel (chlorine coffin).  The Oahu Fire Department also maintains ¿A¿ and ¿B¿ kits and a chlorine recovery vessel.

Anhydrous Ammonia:
Worst-case release scenario - Failure of the largest DOT ammonia transport tank when filled to

maximum filling capacity would release 30,000 lbs of anhydrous ammonia within a 10-minute time frame.  It is assumed that the entire contents of the storage tank are released as a buoyant vapor cloud.  The ERPG-2 (anhydrous ammonia is 0.14 mg/L [~200 ppm]) toxic endpoint was predicted to be 2.0 miles downwind of the facility.  The EPA model RMP*Comp was used to estimate the toxic endpoint distance assuming worst-case meteorology of 1.5 m/s stability class F, no mitigation measures, and that the material is stored as liquid under pressure. 

Alternative release scenario - a 2¿ transfer pipe/hose connected to the storage tank falls over and shears off the valve releasing 370 lbs per minutes of anhydrous ammonia per minutes and the emergency response team responded and stopped the leak within 60 minutes.  It is assumed that the 22,200 lbs content of the tank is released as a buoyant vapor cloud.  The ERPG-2 (anhydrous ammonia is 0.14 mg/L [~200 ppm]) toxic endpoint was predicted to be 0.2 miles downwind of the facility.  The EPA model RMP*Comp was used to estimate the toxic endpoint distance assuming average meteorology of 3.0 m/s stability class D, no mitigation measures, and that the material is stored as liquid under pressure.

The BEI Hawaii Facility uses standard DOT transport tank which has internal flow shout off valve and manual emergency shut-off valve which will stop the release quickly to minimize the release of tank contents.

Sulfur Dioxide:
Worst-case release scenario ¿ failure of a 1-ton sulfur dioxide cylinder releases 2,000 pounds of sulfur dioxide within a 10-minute time frame.  It is assumed that the entire contents of the cylinder are released as a dense vapor cloud.  The ERPG-2 toxic endpoint (for sulfur dioxide is 0.0087 mg/L [~3 ppm]) was predicted to be 1.3 miles downwind of the facility.  The EPA model RMP*Comp (version 1.07) was used to estimate the toxic endpoint distance assuming worst-case meteorology of 1.5 m/s stability class F, no mitiga

tion measures, and that the material is stored as liquid under pressure.

Alternative-case release scenario ¿ 1 ton sulfur dioxide cylinder falls over and shears off the valve, leaves a 1¿ circular hole on the cylinder releasing 75 lbs per minutes of releasing 2000 pounds of sulfur dioxide within a 27minute time frame.  It is assumed that the entire contents of the cylinder are released as a dense vapor cloud.  The ERPG-2 toxic endpoint (for chlorine is 0.0087 mg/L [~3 ppm]) was predicted to be 0.2 miles downwind of the facility.  The EPA model RMP*Comp was used to estimate the toxic endpoint distance assuming average meteorology of 3.0 m/s stability class D, no mitigation measures, and that the material is stored as liquid under pressure.

4.  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Steps

The facility complies with the OSHA Process Safety Management rule.   A process safety management plan was written for the facility that includes all of the required elements.   Since the process is storage only, the practices important to the prevention program are the proper storage and handling of the chlorine and anhydrous sulfur dioxide cylinders.  Dry, isolated and fireproof storage spaces are provided where the temperature of the vicinity of the cylinders never reaches 140 degrees Fahrenheit.  Proper loading and unloading of cylinders from trucks are very important to prevent cylinders from falling and cause possible damage to the valve area.  Training and careful work practices are the key to preventing accidental damage to the cylinders.

5.  Five-Year Accident History

The facility has not experienced any accidents involved to RMP regulated substance during the past five years.  This is understandable because the process is mainly storage only with minimal using of the chlorine on site.  This site had a sulfuric acid spill on Nov. 25 1999 but it is not RMP regulated substance.

6.  Emergency Response Program

The BEI Hawaii ¿ Barber¿s Point facility

is classified as a non-responding facility.  As such, BEI Hawaii has developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure employee/community safety, rather than a full-fledged emergency response with an in-house response team.  The BEI Hawaii - Barber¿s Point Facility has developed its own procedures as outlined in the BEI Hawaii Safety and Health Program incorporating information from Chlorine Institute Pamphlet 64, Emergency Response Plans for Chlorine Facilities and others.  BEI Hawaii has coordinated response to incidents with the Honolulu Fire Department Hazmat Team located in Oahu.  Operators are capable, however, of responding to incidental releases such as routine tightening of a valve, for example. 

BEI Hawaii ¿ Barber¿s Point facility personnel will only perform defensive mitigation measures (i.e., secure areas, initiate water spray, etc.,) to limit the release until a response team arrives to establish the incident command.  We have discussed this program with the Local Emergency Planning Committee and the Honolulu Fire Department.  In addition, BEI Hawaii has arranged with local response contractors to deal with potential releases at the facility.  

7.  Planned change to improve safety

There is no plan to change the present operation for chlorine, sulfur dioxide, and anhydrous ammonia primarily because the process is storage.  BEI Hawaii eliminated several other chemicals and reduced chemical inventory amount.  Chlorine use especially by swimming pools and sewage treatment plants is being eliminated and substituted with bleach or hypochlorite in powdered or tablet form depending on the size of the facility.  This will enable BEI Hawaii to reduce the chlorine inventory.
